Stem: Oxpeckers eat ticks on zebras. Drag and drop the labels to describe the relationships between organisms (predator-prey, mutualism, parasitism).
Image/Diagram Description: Image showing oxpeckers on zebras with drag-drop labels for organism relationships
Choices: Labels: predator-prey / mutualism / parasitism
Correct Answer: TEI — drag labels to match relationships
Scenario Justification: Real ecological scenario with oxpeckers and zebras. Students must classify organism relationships by dragging labels. The scenario is engaging but the content (symbiotic relationships and food web classification) aligns to Grade 5 LS2 rather than Grade 4 NGSS.
SEP Justification: Students classify organism relationships by matching labels. Engages Analyzing and Interpreting Data at a basic classification level — limited reasoning beyond recall of relationship definitions.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of symbiotic relationships (mutualism, parasitism, predator-prey). This content is not part of Grade 4 NGSS — it aligns to 5-LS2 (ecosystems interactions). Recall-level within the misaligned content.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Patterns (organisms form recurring relationship types) but students are not asked to reason with the CCC — only to classify.
Key Recommendation: Content misalignment: symbiotic relationships are Grade 5 NGSS (5-LS2). The drag-drop format adds interactivity but not cognitive depth. Realign to Grade 4 standards or redesign to ask students to explain WHY each relationship benefits or harms each organism.

Stem: Stem in image — limited evaluation.
Image/Diagram Description: Image-based question with answer choices A through D
Choices: A) [in image], B) [in image], C) [in image], D) [in image]
Scenario Justification: Stem is entirely embedded in an image and was not extracted. Cannot evaluate scenario quality. Conservatively scored.
SEP Justification: Cannot evaluate practice engagement without the stem. Conservatively scored as recall.
DCI Justification: Cannot evaluate DCI depth without knowing the content. Conservatively scored.
CCC Justification: Cannot evaluate CCC engagement without the stem.
Key Recommendation: Stem was not extractable from the image. Full evaluation requires the original test image. Recommend providing text-accessible versions of all questions for accessibility and evaluation purposes.

Stem: An object is moving across a surface. What will happen to the object due to friction?
Choices: A) Speed up, B) Stay the same, C) Slow down and stop, D) Change direction
Scenario Justification: Simple question about friction's effect on motion. Minimal scenario — no real-world context or investigation framing. Direct recall of a basic concept.
SEP Justification: No science practice engaged beyond recall. Students select the known effect of friction.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that friction converts kinetic energy to heat and slows objects. Basic recall of friction's effect on motion. Aligns to 4-PS3-3.
CCC Justification: No CCC engaged. No reasoning about patterns or cause-and-effect required.
Key Recommendation: Pure recall of friction's effect. Redesign with a scenario providing data about different surfaces and asking students to predict and explain differences in stopping distance using Cause and Effect reasoning.

Stem: Fleas live on a wolf and feed on its blood. Describe the relationship between the fleas and the wolf.
Choices: Labels or options related to: mutualism / parasitism / predator-prey / commensalism
Scenario Justification: Simple organism relationship identification. The flea-wolf scenario is real but the question is direct recall of parasitism. Content aligns to Grade 5 LS2 rather than Grade 4 NGSS.
SEP Justification: Students identify a parasitic relationship. No science practice beyond recall and classification.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that parasitism involves one organism benefiting at the expense of another. Recall-level. Content misaligned to Grade 5.
Key Recommendation: Content misalignment: organism relationships are Grade 5 NGSS (5-LS2). This is essentially the same concept as Q1 (parasitism) making it redundant. Realign to Grade 4 standards and reduce redundancy.

Stem: Drag and drop items to classify materials or layers as 'Mostly solid.' [Likely about Earth's layers or states of matter.]
Image/Diagram Description: Image with drag-drop interface for classification
Choices: Labels related to solid/liquid/gas or Earth layer classifications
Scenario Justification: Drag-drop classification task. The phrase 'mostly solid' suggests Earth's layers (inner core is solid; outer core is liquid; mantle is mostly solid). Alternatively could be states of matter. Limited context for full evaluation.
SEP Justification: Students classify materials or layers by dragging labels. Engages Analyzing and Interpreting Data at a classification level. The drag-drop format adds interactivity but not necessarily depth.
DCI Justification: If about Earth's layers this tests understanding of Earth's internal structure — partially aligned to 4-ESS2-2. If states of matter it is more basic physical science recall.
CCC Justification: Classification tasks implicitly engage Patterns but no deep CCC reasoning required.
Key Recommendation: The drag-drop format is interactive but the task appears to be recall-level classification. Redesign to provide evidence (e.g. seismic wave data) and ask students to infer which layers are solid vs liquid based on evidence.

Stem: [Stem in image — two-part question. Part A likely asks students to classify organisms in a food web. References herbivores and producers.]
Image/Diagram Description: Food web diagram with organisms to classify
Choices: Options likely include: herbivore / carnivore / omnivore / producer / consumer
Scenario Justification: Two-part food web classification question. References herbivores and producers suggesting students classify organisms by trophic level. Content aligns to Grade 5 LS2.
SEP Justification: If students classify organisms using food web evidence this engages Analyzing and Interpreting Data at a basic classification level.
DCI Justification: Food web trophic level classification (producers, herbivores, carnivores) is Grade 5 content. Recall-level within the misaligned content.
CCC Justification: Classification may implicitly engage Patterns but no deep CCC reasoning.
Key Recommendation: Food web classification is Grade 5 NGSS content. Two-part structure adds some depth but the task appears to be recall-level classification of trophic levels.

Stem: [Part B of two-part question. Students select organisms that are herbivores or producers from a food web. Answer: B and E.]
Choices: A) [organism], B) [correct], C) [organism], D) [organism], E) [correct]
Scenario Justification: Part B continues the food web classification task. Students must select specific organisms that fit a category (herbivores or producers). Multi-select format adds some complexity.
SEP Justification: Multi-select format requires students to evaluate each organism against classification criteria. Slightly higher demand than single-select but still classification-level.
DCI Justification: Same Grade 5 content as 22a. Students apply trophic level definitions to identify specific organisms.
CCC Justification: No deep CCC engagement beyond basic classification.
Key Recommendation: Multi-select format adds slight complexity but the task remains recall-level classification of Grade 5 content. Realign to Grade 4 standards.

Stem: Drag and drop organisms to complete a food chain. [Likely involves ordering organisms by energy flow from producer to top consumer.]
Image/Diagram Description: Food chain diagram with drag-drop slots for organisms
Choices: Organisms to arrange in food chain order (e.g. phytoplankton → zooplankton → krill → squid or similar)
Scenario Justification: Food chain ordering task. Students must sequence organisms by energy flow from producer to consumer. Content aligns to Grade 5 LS2 rather than Grade 4 NGSS. The drag-drop format adds interactivity.
SEP Justification: Students sequence organisms in a food chain which engages Developing and Using Models at a basic level — constructing a simple energy flow model.
DCI Justification: Food chain sequencing is Grade 5 content (5-LS2). Tests understanding of energy flow from producers through consumers. Application-level within misaligned content.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Energy and Matter (energy flows through food chains) and Patterns (consistent pattern of producer → consumer hierarchy) but students are not asked to reason deeply with these CCCs.
Key Recommendation: Food chain content is Grade 5 NGSS. The drag-drop sequencing adds interactivity but not cognitive depth. Realign to Grade 4 standards. If retained add a follow-up asking what happens to energy at each level.

Stem: [Food chain question — answer C. Options reference marine organisms: squid, phytoplankton, zooplankton, krill. Photosynthesis mentioned.]
Image/Diagram Description: Marine food chain diagram with organism options
Choices: A) squid → phytoplankton → zooplankton → krill, B) krill → zooplankton → phytoplankton → squid, C) phytoplankton → zooplankton → krill → squid, D) zooplankton → krill → squid → phytoplankton
Scenario Justification: Marine food chain sequencing question. Students must order organisms from producer (phytoplankton) through consumers. Photosynthesis reference connects producers to energy source. Grade 5 content.
SEP Justification: Students apply understanding of energy flow to sequence marine organisms. Engages Developing and Using Models at a basic level — selecting the correct food chain model.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that phytoplankton are producers (photosynthesis) and energy flows through zooplankton → krill → squid. Grade 5 content applied at recall/application level.
CCC Justification: Engages Energy and Matter (energy flows from sun → producers → consumers) at a basic level. The photosynthesis reference connects to energy input.
Key Recommendation: Marine food chain content is Grade 5 NGSS. The inclusion of photosynthesis adds a conceptual layer but the task is essentially recall of food chain ordering. Realign to Grade 4 or redesign to ask students to explain what happens to energy at each trophic level.

Stem: What causes the pattern of day and night on Earth? [Options reference the sun's rotation on its axis and likely Earth's rotation.]
Choices: A) The sun's rotation on its axis, B) Earth's rotation on its axis, C) The moon's orbit around Earth, D) Earth's orbit around the sun
Scenario Justification: Simple recall question about the cause of day and night. The mention of 'the sun's rotation on its axis' as a distractor suggests testing basic understanding. Content aligns to Grade 5 ESS1 rather than Grade 4 NGSS.
SEP Justification: No science practice engaged. Pure recall of what causes day and night.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that Earth's rotation causes day and night. This content aligns to 5-ESS1-2 (Grade 5) not Grade 4 standards. Recall-level.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Cause and Effect (rotation causes day/night) but at a trivially simple level.
Key Recommendation: Content misalignment: day/night cycle is Grade 5 NGSS (5-ESS1-2). Pure recall question. If retained redesign with a scenario showing shadow data at different times and asking students to explain the pattern using Earth's rotation.

Stem: Drag and drop to place the snake in the correct position in the food web. [Students must identify the snake's trophic level and position in the food web.]
Image/Diagram Description: Food web diagram with a drag-drop slot for snake placement
Choices: Snake placement options within food web structure
Correct Answer: TEI — place snake in food web
Scenario Justification: Food web placement task requiring students to understand what snakes eat and what eats snakes. Content aligns to Grade 5 LS2. The drag-drop format requires understanding of trophic relationships.
SEP Justification: Students construct part of a food web model by placing an organism. Engages Developing and Using Models at a basic level — students must understand the organism's role in the web.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of food web structure and where a secondary consumer (snake) fits. Grade 5 content. Application-level within the food web context.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Energy and Matter (energy flow through food web) and Systems and System Models (food web as a system of interconnected relationships).
Key Recommendation: Another food web question (Grade 5 content). The model-construction aspect of placing an organism adds some depth over simple identification. However this is the 8th or 9th ecosystem/food web question on this test — severe over-testing of misaligned content.

Stem: [Diagrams showing the orbits of Earth, Moon, and Sun. Students likely identify which diagram correctly shows the orbital relationships.]
Image/Diagram Description: Diagrams showing orbital models of Earth-Moon-Sun system
Choices: A) [diagram], B) [diagram], C) [diagram], D) [diagram]
Scenario Justification: Earth-Moon-Sun orbital relationship question. Students must identify the correct model of orbital relationships from diagrams. Content aligns to Grade 5 ESS1 rather than Grade 4 NGSS.
SEP Justification: Students evaluate competing models of the Earth-Moon-Sun system. Engages Developing and Using Models at a basic level — selecting the correct model rather than constructing one.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of Earth-Moon-Sun orbital relationships. This content is 5-ESS1 (Grade 5). Application-level within the misaligned content — students must know that Earth orbits Sun and Moon orbits Earth.
CCC Justification: Engages Systems and System Models (Earth-Moon-Sun as a system) at a basic level. Students must understand the nested orbital relationships.
Key Recommendation: Content misalignment: Earth-Moon-Sun orbital system is Grade 5 NGSS (5-ESS1). The diagram-comparison format adds visual reasoning. Realign to Grade 4 standards.
